full_title_en: Behavioral Observational Pain Scale (BOPS) for Post-Op Pediatric Pain
medium_description_en: Quantifies post-operative pain for children aged 1-7 years.
instructions_en:
This pain scale is for use in patients 1-7 years old.

One can also use the Children’s Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS) for Post-Op Pediatric Pain as an alternative to the BOPS.

seo.meta_description_en: The Behavioral Observational Pain Scale (BOPS) is a post-operative pain measurement scale for children aged 1-7 years.
seo.keywords_en: bops, post op peds, post op ped pain, peds pain scale, post op pain scale, children pain scale, child pain post-op, post surgery pain

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: Allows for simple, quick pain assessment in children 1-7 years old after surgery.

next_steps.advice_en: The BOPS is easy to use when assessing pediatric pain.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: The BOPS requires close and attentive clinical evaluation of facial expressions, vocalization and body language.

about.more_info_en:
Pain assessments should be performed:

  • Every 3 hours
  • 15-20 minutes after IV administration of analgesics
  • 30-45 minutes after oral/rectal administration

Consider analgesia for scores ≥ 3.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Anand KJ, Craig KD. New perspectives on definition of pain. Pain 1996; 67:3-6.

Validation.text: Hesselgard K, Larsson S, Romner B, Strömblad LG, Reinstrup P. Validity and reliability of the Behavioural Observational Pain Scale for postoperative pain measurement in children 1-7 years of age. Pediatr Crit Care Med. 2007 Mar;8(2):102-8.

creator_info.about_en: Kanwaljeet J. S. Anand, MBBS, PhD, is a professor of pediatrics, anesthesiology, and perioperative and pain medicine at Stanford University in California. Previously, he was a professor of medicine in the department of pediatrics at the University of Tennessee Health Science Center. Dr. Anand’s primary research focuses on pain management and treatment disorders, specifically in pediatric patients.

options.label: Negative facial expression, grimace, distorted face
Completely quiet, sobbing and/or complaining but not because of pain
Crying, screaming and/or complaining about pain
Inactive, laying, relaxed with all extremities or sitting, walking
Restless movements, shifting fashion and/or touching wound or wound area
Lying rigid and/or drawn up with arms and legs to the body
